claim: London gets more international arrivals than Paris.

supporting.text: London has consistently ranked as one of the top global cities for international tourist arrivals, according to data from the World Tourism Organization (UNWTO).

attacks.text: London has consistently ranked as one of the top global cities for international tourist arrivals, according to data from the World Tourism Organization (UNWTO).
Paris has historically been the most visited city in the world, with higher tourist numbers than London in recent years, as reported by the Paris Convention and Visitors Bureau.
The UNWTO data cited by A1 includes transit passengers and business travelers, which may inflate London's numbers compared to Paris's leisure-focused tourism.
The methodology used by the Paris Convention and Visitors Bureau may exclude day-trippers and regional visitors, undercounting Paris's true tourist volume.
London's multi-airport system (Heathrow, Gatwick, etc.) handles more international flights than Paris, directly contributing to higher arrival counts in UNWTO data.

supporting.text: London's Heathrow Airport is one of the busiest international airports in the world by passenger traffic, indicating higher international arrivals compared to Paris airports.

attacks.text: London's Heathrow Airport is one of the busiest international airports in the world by passenger traffic, indicating higher international arrivals compared to Paris airports.
Paris has multiple major international airports (Charles de Gaulle, Orly, Beauvais), collectively handling more international arrivals than Heathrow alone.
Heathrow's passenger traffic includes a significant portion of transit passengers who do not actually arrive in London, whereas Paris airports primarily handle direct arrivals.
Charles de Gaulle Airport also serves as a major transit hub, meaning not all its passenger traffic represents arrivals in Paris.

supporting.text: Paris has historically been a leading destination for international tourists, with attractions like the Eiffel Tower and Louvre drawing millions annually, potentially rivaling London.

attacks.text: Paris has historically been a leading destination for international tourists, with attractions like the Eiffel Tower and Louvre drawing millions annually, potentially rivaling London.
London consistently ranks higher than Paris in international tourist arrivals, with Heathrow Airport being the busiest in Europe by passenger traffic.
While Heathrow is busier, Paris has multiple major airports (Charles de Gaulle, Orly) that collectively handle more international passengers than Heathrow alone.
London's tourism appeal extends beyond air travel, with Eurostar arrivals from Europe adding significantly to its international visitor numbers.

supporting.text: The UK's Office for National Statistics reports higher international visitor numbers to London than France's national statistics report for Paris in recent years.

attacks.text: The UK's Office for National Statistics reports higher international visitor numbers to London than France's national statistics report for Paris in recent years.
The definition of 'international arrivals' may differ between the UK and France, such as whether transit passengers are counted.
Both the UK and France follow UNWTO guidelines for tourism statistics, minimizing definitional discrepancies.
The data excludes same-day visitors, which may disproportionately affect Paris due to its proximity to other European cities.
Same-day visitors contribute minimally to economic impact, making overnight visitor statistics more relevant for comparison.

supporting.text: London's status as a global financial and cultural hub contributes to higher business and leisure travel, increasing international arrivals compared to Paris.

attacks.text: London's status as a global financial and cultural hub contributes to higher business and leisure travel, increasing international arrivals compared to Paris.
Paris remains the most visited city in the world by international tourists, with higher leisure travel numbers than London, according to recent tourism statistics.
London's financial hub status primarily drives business travel, which is less frequent than leisure travel, and does not necessarily translate to higher total international arrivals.
Paris has a more centralized tourism infrastructure, including iconic landmarks like the Eiffel Tower and Louvre, which attract more short-term visitors than London's dispersed attractions.
London's cultural diversity and events (e.g., West End, festivals) attract a broader range of international visitors year-round, compensating for Paris's landmark-centric tourism.

supporting.text: Paris benefits from its central location in Europe and extensive high-speed rail connections, which may boost its international visitor numbers relative to London.

attacks.text: Paris benefits from its central location in Europe and extensive high-speed rail connections, which may boost its international visitor numbers relative to London.
London has a larger international airport system (Heathrow, Gatwick, etc.) with more direct global flights, making it more accessible for long-haul travelers.
Paris's rail connections primarily serve European travelers, while London's aviation hub status attracts a more diverse global audience.
Tourism data from 2019 shows London had 21.7 million international arrivals, while Paris had 19.1 million, supporting London's lead.
Paris's appeal is concentrated in leisure tourism, while London's broader business and cultural offerings draw more varied international visitors.
